document_title: Acute pancreatitis: causes, symptoms, complications and diagnosis
subsection_content:
To diagnose acute pancreatitis, doctors can apply the following methods:(5)
Tests: For initial evaluation when acute pancreatitis is suspected to be associated with abnormalities, such as cholestasis, hypercalcemia, or severe hyperlipidemia... Doctors can rely on these results to confirm or diagnose the etiology of pancreatitis.; Tests: For initial evaluation when acute pancreatitis is suspected to be associated with abnormalities, such as cholestasis, hypercalcemia, or severe hyperlipidemia... Doctors can rely on these results to confirm or diagnose the etiology of pancreatitis.
Ultrasound: Abdominal ultrasound is recommended in all patients to evaluate for gallstones, biliary dilatation or other causes such as appendicitis, cholecystitis, etc.; Ultrasound: Abdominal ultrasound is recommended in all patients to evaluate for gallstones, biliary dilation or other causes such as appendicitis, cholecystitis, etc.
Chest X-ray: Often performed in cases of acute pancreatitis to evaluate pleural effusion, as well as lung parenchymal damage. This is a sign of the severity of acute pancreatitis with a high risk of death.; Chest X-ray: Often performed in cases of acute pancreatitis to evaluate pleural effusion, as well as lung parenchymal damage. This is a sign of the severity of acute pancreatitis with a high risk of death.
CT scan: In cases where the diagnosis is unclear but pancreatitis is suspected, a computed tomography (CT) scan with intravenous contrast will be performed to confirm or exclude the diagnosis. CT is also recommended in cases where the patient does not improve or worsens despite aggressive resuscitation; CT scan: In cases where the diagnosis is unclear but pancreatitis is suspected, a computed tomography (CT) scan with intravenous contrast will be performed to confirm or exclude the diagnosis. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) or endoscopic ultrasound (EUS): These methods will be indicated when the cause of pancreatitis is not found with the above assessment.; Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) or endoscopic ultrasound (EUS): These methods will be indicated when the cause of pancreatitis is not found with the above assessment.
